title: Ernest Troubridge
text:
<a href="Admiral%20%28Royal%20Navy%29">Admiral</a> Sir Ernest Charles Thomas Troubridge, (15 July 1862 – 28 January 1926) was an officer of the <a href="Royal%20Navy">Royal Navy</a> who served during the <a href="First%20World%20War">First World War</a>.
Troubridge was born into a family with substantial military connections, with several of his forebears being distinguished naval officers. He too embarked on a career in the navy, rising through the ranks during the late <a href="Victorian%20era">Victorian period</a>, and commanding ships in the <a href="Mediterranean">Mediterranean</a>. He served as a <a href="Military%20attach%C3%A9">naval attaché</a> to several powers, including the <a href="Empire%20of%20Japan">Empire of Japan</a> during the <a href="Russo-Japanese%20War">Russo-Japanese War</a>. He spent some time immediately before the outbreak of the First World War as a staff officer and assisted in the drawing up of strategic plans to be adopted in the event of war, though these were later rejected. He returned to seagoing service just prior to the outbreak of war, and commanded a cruiser squadron in the Mediterranean with the rank of rear-admiral. Here his promising career was blighted by the events surrounding <a href="Pursuit%20of%20Goeben%20and%20Breslau">the pursuit</a> of two German warships, and . Despite being outclassed by the German warships, Troubridge intended to engage them, but was convinced otherwise by his <a href="flag%20captain">flag captain</a> and allowed them to escape to <a href="Constantinople">Constantinople</a>. He and his commanding officer were heavily criticised for their failure to intercept the German ships, particularly when it subsequently appeared that they became influential in the Turkish decision to enter the war. Troubridge was court-martialled and although he was acquitted, his reputation had been damaged.
Troubridge never had another seagoing command, but did command naval detachments and flotillas on the <a href="Danube">Danube</a> during the Balkan campaigns, winning the respect of Serbian Crown Prince <a href="Alexander%20I%20of%20Yugoslavia">Alexander</a>. After the war he served on the <a href="Commissions%20of%20the%20Danube%20River">Danube Commission</a> and was promoted to admiral, but remained out of favour with the <a href="British%20Admiralty">Admiralty</a>. He spent several years as president of the commission, retiring in 1924 and dying in 1926. He had married twice; his second wife, the sculptor <a href="Una%20Vincenzo%2C%20Lady%20Troubridge">Margot Elena Gertrude Taylor</a>, left him to begin a lesbian relationship with the writer <a href="Radclyffe%20Hall">Marguerite Radclyffe-Hall</a>.
Family and early life.
Ernest Troubridge was born in <a href="Hampstead">Hampstead</a>, London, on 15 July 1862, the third son of <a href="Sir%20Thomas%20Troubridge%2C%203rd%20Baronet">Sir Thomas St Vincent Hope Cochrane Troubridge</a> and his wife Louisa Jane (née Gurney, a niece of <a href="Elizabeth%20Fry">Elizabeth Fry</a>, the Quaker and prison reformer). Thomas Troubridge had served in the army during the <a href="Crimean%20War">Crimean War</a>, and had lost his right leg and left foot at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Inkerman">Battle of Inkerman</a>. The family had a particularly strong naval tradition, Ernest's great-grandfather, <a href="Sir%20Thomas%20Troubridge%2C%201st%20Baronet">Sir Thomas Troubridge, 1st Baronet</a>, had fought alongside <a href="Horatio%20Nelson%2C%201st%20Viscount%20Nelson">Nelson</a> at <a href="Battle%20of%20Cape%20St%20Vincent%20%281797%29">Cape St Vincent</a>, while his grandfather, <a href="Sir%20Edward%20Troubridge%2C%202nd%20Baronet">Sir Edward Troubridge, 2nd Baronet</a>, had also been an admiral. Ernest was also more distantly related to the distinguished admirals <a href="Alexander%20Cochrane">Sir Alexander Cochrane</a> and <a href="Thomas%20Cochrane%2C%2010th%20Earl%20of%20Dundonald">Thomas Cochrane, Lord Cochrane</a>. Ernest Troubridge briefly attended <a href="Wellington%20College%2C%20Berkshire">Wellington College</a> before joining the Royal Navy in 1875. He attended the <a href="Britannia%20Royal%20Naval%20College">Royal Naval College</a>, at <a href="Dartmouth%2C%20Devon">Dartmouth</a> as a naval cadet, and by 1884 had been promoted to lieutenant. During his service with the fleet he was awarded the silver medal of the <a href="Royal%20Humane%20Society">Royal Humane Society</a>, when in 1888 he saved the life of a young seaman who had fallen overboard in the night while their ship was in <a href="Suda%20Bay">Suda Bay</a>, <a href="Crete">Crete</a>.
Rise through the ranks.
Troubridge was promoted to the rank of commander in 1895, serving with the <a href="Mediterranean%20Fleet">Mediterranean Fleet</a> aboard the <a href="flagship">flagship</a> of the fleet's second in command, , initially Rear-Admiral <a href="Robert%20Harris%20%28Royal%20Navy%20officer%29">Sir Robert Harris</a>, and later Rear-Admiral <a href="Gerard%20Noel%20%28Royal%20Navy%20officer%29">Sir Gerard Noel</a>. He was promoted to <a href="Captain%20%28Royal%20Navy%29">captain</a> 17 July 1901 and went on to serve as a <a href="Military%20attach%C3%A9">naval attaché</a> to several powers, based at first in <a href="Vienna">Vienna</a>, and from 1902 in <a href="Madrid">Madrid</a>. He became a naval attaché in <a href="Tokyo">Tokyo</a> later in 1902, and served as such until 1904. With the outbreak of the <a href="Russo-Japanese%20War">Russo-Japanese War</a> he went to sea with the Japanese warships and was present at the <a href="Battle%20of%20Chemulpo%20Bay">Battle of Chemulpo Bay</a> and the subsequent <a href="Battle%20of%20Port%20Arthur">operations</a> off <a href="L%C3%BCshunkou%20District">Port Arthur</a>. After the conclusion of the war Troubridge was awarded the <a href="Order%20of%20the%20Rising%20Sun">Order of the Rising Sun</a> by the Japanese, while the British government appointed him a <a href="Companion%20of%20the%20Order%20of%20St%20Michael%20and%20St%20George">Companion of the Order of St Michael and St George</a> and a <a href="Member%20of%20the%20Royal%20Victorian%20Order">Member of the Royal Victorian Order</a>. He took command of the <a href="battleship">battleship</a> , serving as <a href="flag%20captain">flag captain</a> to the commander of the Mediterranean Fleet, Admiral <a href="Charles%20Carter%20Drury">Sir Charles Drury</a>.
After the expiration of this posting Troubridge spent the years between 1908 and 1910 as <a href="Commodore%20%28Royal%20Navy%29">commodore</a> commanding the royal naval barracks at <a href="Chatham%20Dockyard">Chatham</a>, and in 1910 became Private <a href="Naval%20Secretary">Naval Secretary</a> to the <a href="First%20Lord%20of%20the%20Admiralty">First Lord of the Admiralty</a>. Until 1911 this was <a href="Reginald%20McKenna">Reginald McKenna</a>, who was succeeded that year by <a href="Winston%20Churchill">Winston Churchill</a>. Troubridge was promoted to flag rank in March 1911 with his promotion to rear-admiral, and in 1912 he became chief of the War Staff. During his time on the War Staff he was involved in the drawing up of plans for naval strategy in the event of war. The plans, which involved the establishment of a massive cordon of warships in British waters, provoked criticism from a number of naval officers, and were eventually shown to be unsound in a series of naval exercises and manoeuvres in the summer of 1912. Churchill arranged for Troubridge to leave office at the end of the year, replacing him with Vice-Admiral <a href="Henry%20Jackson%20%28Royal%20Navy%20officer%29">Sir Henry Jackson</a>. Troubridge returned to active service at sea in January 1913 with his appointment to command the Mediterranean Fleet's cruiser squadron, consisting of , , and , under the fleet's commander-in-chief, Admiral <a href="Archibald%20Berkeley%20Milne">Sir Berkeley Milne</a>. During this period Troubridge flew his flag aboard "Defence".
First World War.
Pursuit of "Goeben" and "Breslau".
On the entry of the British to the First World War in early August 1914, <a href="German%20Empire">Germany</a> had two ships in the Mediterranean, forming their <a href="Mediterranean%20Division">"Mittelmeerdivision"</a>, the <a href="battlecruiser">battlecruiser</a> and the <a href="light%20cruiser">light cruiser</a> . The German ships, under Rear-Admiral <a href="Wilhelm%20Souchon">Wilhelm Souchon</a>, had been shadowed by a British battlecruiser force, while Milne deployed his fleet to bottle up the German ships. After carrying out a shore bombardment, the Germans were observed to coal at <a href="Messina">Messina</a>, causing Milne to send most of his force to wait west of <a href="Sicily">Sicily</a>, to prevent Souchon from interfering with French troop convoys. Troubridge and his force of four cruisers were sent to cruise west of <a href="Cephalonia">Cephalonia</a> in case Souchon should try to enter the <a href="Adriatic%20Sea">Adriatic</a> and join the <a href="Austro-Hungarian%20Navy">Austro-Hungarian fleet</a>. The Germans sailed from Messina on 6 August, and were observed to be making for the Adriatic. They were shadowed by the light cruiser , which reported that the Germans were not intending to enter the Adriatic, but were in fact heading east towards <a href="Cape%20Matapan">Cape Matapan</a>. "Gloucester" carried out an attack on the German ships, hoping to slow them down sufficiently for Troubridge's cruisers to bring them to action. However, Troubridge had received orders from Milne in late January that, on the instructions of the First Lord of the Admiralty, Winston Churchill, the British force in the Mediterranean was not to engage superior forces. Churchill had intended this to mean the Austro-Hungarian and Italian fleets, but Troubridge took it to include the Germans. The orders transmitted to Milne stated that his primary objective was to support the transport of French troops, with the engagement of individual German ships a secondary objective. A superior force should only be engaged in combination with the French.
From his experiences in the Russo-Japanese War, Troubridge was aware that modern naval ordnance could devastate his squadron and that the "Goeben"s 11-inch guns considerably outranged his own, which consisted of 9.2-inch and 7.5-inch guns. A night attack on the German force using the cruiser failed when the British ship failed to make contact, so Troubridge attempted to catch the Germans in narrow waters to reduce the range. Troubridge was still unaware of German intentions, and feared they might double-back to the north east and effect a junction with the Austro-Hungarian fleet. Troubridge resolved to intercept the German squadron and headed southwards to do so, but his flag captain, <a href="Fawcet%20Wray">Fawcet Wray</a>, argued against seeking battle. Troubridge was reluctant to do so anyway, knowing that his ships would be both outranged and attacking in daylight, but felt it was the only honourable option. Wray argued that it would be suicide for the squadron to fight the bigger and longer-ranging guns of the "Goeben" and as Wray had a particular reputation in the fleet as an expert on gunnery, Troubridge allowed himself to be persuaded. In tears, Troubridge ordered the chase to be abandoned, a decision that caused Wray to say 'Sir, this is the bravest thing you have ever done.' Troubridge's signal was transmitted shortly afterwards: 4.49am, 7/8/14, to Milne:<br>Being only able to meet "Goeben" outside the range of our guns and inside his, I have abandoned the chase with my squadron. "Goeben" evidently going to the Eastern Mediterranean. The chase abandoned, the Germans made it to <a href="Istanbul">Constantinople</a>, and the ships were almost immediately turned over to the Turkish Navy.
Court-martial.
Both Troubridge and Milne came under considerable criticism for their failure to engage and destroy the German squadron, criticism which intensified when it appeared that the presence of the German ships had been influential in the subsequent Turkish decision to enter the war. Troubridge was ordered back to Britain in September, and faced a court of inquiry held at the Navigation School, <a href="Portsmouth">Portsmouth</a>. After investigating the events surrounding the chase of "Goeben" and "Breslau", the court of inquiry decided to court-martial Troubridge on the grounds of his failure to engage the enemy. The court martial was held on board , moored at <a href="Isle%20of%20Portland">Portland</a>, from 5 to 9 November 1914. After deliberations the court came to the conclusion that the charge was not proved, owing to the nature of his orders and the <a href="British%20Admiralty">Admiralty</a>'s failure to clarify them, and Troubridge was 'fully and honourably acquitted'. Despite this victory the criticism lingered, with accusations that he had let the fleet down. Neither Troubridge nor Milne received another seagoing command, and in January 1915 Troubridge was appointed to head the British naval mission to <a href="Serbia">Serbia</a>.
Balkan service.
The British naval mission to Serbia was intended to support Serbian efforts to resist the Austro-Hungarian flotilla, consisting of <a href="monitor%20%28warship%29">monitors</a> and patrol vessels, operating on the <a href="Danube">Danube</a>. For this task Troubridge commanded a small group of seaman and <a href="Royal%20Marines">marines</a> armed with eight <a href="QF%204.7-inch%20Gun%20Mk%20I%E2%80%93IV">4.7-inch naval guns</a>. They were later reinforced with a 45-foot <a href="picket%20boat">picket boat</a> fitted with <a href="torpedo">torpedo</a> dropping gear. Allied control of the Danube became strategically vital after the <a href="Gallipoli%20Campaign">Gallipoli Campaign</a> began, as it prevented river-borne supplies from reaching the <a href="Black%20Sea">Black Sea</a>, from where they could be transported to <a href="Turkey">Turkey</a>. Despite initial success in preventing Austro-Hungarian domination of the waterway, the entry of Bulgaria to the war and the combined Austrian-German-Bulgarian offensive in October caused the disintegration of the Serbian position. Troubridge and his force retreated with the Serbian army to the Adriatic coast, reaching the small port of <a href="San%20Giovanni%20di%20Medua">San Giovanni di Medua</a>. Troubridge took command of the evacuation and oversaw the withdrawal of the remains of the army and many thousands of refugees to <a href="Corfu">Corfu</a> throughout December and January. On 16 December he was joined by Lieutenant Commander <a href="Charles%20Lester%20Kerr">Charles Lester Kerr</a>, his flag-lieutenant, who escaped with his men across the Albanian mountains during an attempt to save the remaining 4.7-inch guns. They and their party left on 21 January in an Italian destroyer and transferred to HMS "Queen" based in Tarranto, Italy.
Impressed with his services, Serbian Crown Prince <a href="Alexander%20I%20of%20Yugoslavia">Alexander</a> requested Troubridge as his personal advisor and aide. Troubridge, having been promoted to vice-admiral in June 1916, went out to <a href="Salonika">Salonika</a> to join the reformed Serbian armies. He remained in the Balkans throughout the campaigns of the next two years, which culminated in the final collapse of Bulgaria in September 1918. The French commander in chief in the area, <a href="Louis%20Franchet%20d%27Esp%C3%A8rey">Louis Franchet d'Espèrey</a>, appointed Troubridge admiral commanding on the Danube. Troubridge quickly requested the formation of a new naval brigade, to be supported with artillery and torpedo gear in order to prosecute the Danube campaign, but this was rejected by the Admiralty in favour of a gunboat flotilla. Displeased by Troubridge's acceptance of a French appointment, they tried to prevent him from having command of the flotilla.
Post-war service.
Troubridge remained in the Balkans for several months after the end of the war, and returned to Britain in early 1919, having been promoted to admiral in January 1919. While he was able to restore his position, he attempted to intervene without orders in the establishment of <a href="B%C3%A9la%20Kun">Béla Kun</a>'s <a href="Hungarian%20Soviet%20Republic">Hungarian Soviet Republic</a> in March 1919. His actions brought questionable results, and he remained out of favour with the Admiralty. His experience in the Danube area led to his appointment as president of a provisional inter-allied <a href="Commissions%20of%20the%20Danube%20River">Danube Commission</a> in 1919. He was replaced by a representative favoured by the <a href="Foreign%20Office">Foreign Office</a> on the establishment of the permanent international Danube commission, but when this representative, and a representative favoured by the Admiralty both departed, Troubridge was recalled in June 1920. He had been created a <a href="Order%20of%20St%20Michael%20and%20St%20George">Knight Commander of the Order of St Michael and St George</a> in June 1919. His tenure as president of the commission lasted until March 1924, during which time he was placed on the retired list by the Admiralty, on the grounds that his salary came from the commission.
Personal life.
Troubridge married Edith Mary Duffus on 29 December 1891. The couple had one surviving son, <a href="Thomas%20Hope%20Troubridge">Thomas Hope Troubridge</a>, who followed his father into the navy and eventually became a vice-admiral. Edith died in 1900 after delivering a stillborn fourth child. Ernest remarried on 10 October 1908. His second wife was the sculptor <a href="Una%20Vincenzo%2C%20Lady%20Troubridge">Margot Elena Gertrude Taylor</a>, more commonly known as Una Vincenzo. The couple had a daughter, but separated in 1919, Una having begun a relationship in 1915 with <a href="Radclyffe%20Hall">Marguerite Radclyffe-Hall</a>. Sir Ernest Troubridge died suddenly in <a href="Biarritz">Biarritz</a> on 28 January 1926, and was buried there.
